EVENT_NARRATIVE: A plethora of records were set across interior northern California for January. The following is from one of our oldest record sites, Downtown Sacramento. The highlights include: the longest dry period (52 days) during the rainy season from Dec. 8th, 2013 to Jan. 28th, 2014 that did not receive measurable rainfall, the third driest January in history since 1950 with 0.20 inches of rainfall which is only 5% of normal, highest January average maximum temperature of 66.1 degrees, new all-time record high for the month of January set on Jan. 24th of 79 degrees, broke the number of days with high temperatures of 70 degrees or higher with 3 days, record high temperatures were set on 12 different days, and lastly, everyday of January 2014 had a daytime high temperature that was above normal for the month for Downtown Sacramento.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January was an abnormally dry and warm month for interior Northern California. Many record high temperatures were broken, and a state-wide drought was declared on January 17th.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of January, 2014.  Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor for much of the region, with exceptional drought detected along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley.  For California as a whole, 2013 was the driest year on record. As  the 2013-2014 winter progresses, little rain has fallen across California. ||On January 17th, Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California. Impacts to the region included: loss of ground water pumping ability, aggressive conservation efforts within many valley communities, lack of well drilling access, ground subsidence along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley, and increasing unemployment due to lack of agricultural employment.  ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. For the first time on record, red flag warnings were issued in January for not only the Southern Sierra Nevada and the Tehachapi Mountains but also the south end of the San Joaquin Valley.||January, 2014 was the 2nd warmest on record in both Bakersfield and Fresno, at 54.2 degrees and 53.2 degrees, respectively.  January was the 7th driest on record for Bakersfield, at 0.12 inches, and the 26th driest at Fresno, with 0.57 inches.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of March, 2014. Extreme to Exceptional drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor for almost the entire Central California region.  This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California.  In addition precipitation deficits began to mount as the region was nearing the end of the bulk of the rainy season with continued deficits.  As the 2013-2014 winter progresses, little rain has fallen across California. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. For the first time on record, red flag warnings were issued in January for not only the Southern Sierra Nevada and the Tehachapi Mountains but also the south end of the San Joaquin Valley.

These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. For the first time on record, red flag warnings were issued in January for not only the Southern Sierra Nevada and the Tehachapi Mountains but also the south end of the San Joaquin Valley.

These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. For the first time on record, red flag warnings were issued in January for not only the Southern Sierra Nevada and the Tehachapi Mountains but also the south end of the San Joaquin Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Impacts to the region included: Reservoirs dropped to low levels (record lows in some cases), farmers limited plantings of some crops and allowed areas of land to go fallow, increased agricultural unemployment and poverty, strong conservation efforts within many communities, increased reliance on shrinking groundwater resources, a decrease in snow-related tourism activity in the Northern Sierra Nevada, and a large increase in fire danger across the Northern Sierra Nevada, Southern Cascades and Coastal Range. Large wildfires such as the King Fire required large scale and very expensive suppression efforts. |For the entire state of California, 2014 was the warmest on record, which further increased the need for water and reduced an already limited snow pack. The Sierra snow pack ended the year at only about half of normal levels.|The California Department of Food and Agricultures Office of Public Relations summarized 2014 California agricultural losses: Direct costs to agriculture total $1.5 billion (revenue losses of $1 billion and $0.5 billion in additional pumping costs). This net revenue loss is about 3 percent of the states total agricultural value. The total statewide economic cost of the 2014 drought is $2.2 billion. The loss of 17,100 seasonal and part-time jobs related to agriculture represents 3.8 percent of farm unemployment. About 428,000 acres, or 5 percent, of irrigated cropland went out of production in the Central Valley, Central Coast and Southern California due to the drought.|The UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences research suggests that northern interior California lost 4115 to 6796 agricultural jobs in 2014. Almond production dropped by 15 percent compared to the 2013. Almonds are the largest crop for the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 17th, 2014, Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California. The drought continued through the year 2014 with well below normal precipitation, though there were brief periods of relief in February/March and December from heavy rains. Exceptional drought was reported by the U.S. Drought Monitor by the end of July for all of Interior Northern California, with the most impacted area being the Northern San Joaquin Valley.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of December, 2014. Although there was heavy rain and snowfall across central California in early December, the later part of December was mainly dry. The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of December, 2014. Although there was heavy rain and snowfall across central California in early December, the later part of December was mainly dry. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A significant drought continues to impact to the region for January, including a large reduction in snow related tourism in the Northern Sierra Nevada. Multiple downhill and cross country ski resorts were forced to close due to a lack of snow. Resorts which remained open were forced to produce artificial snow, and scale back the number of runs open. Other winter activities such as snowmobiling and snow shoeing were also greatly affected by the lack of snow pack. Restaurants and hotels in the area which rely on winter tourism suffered a significant drop in business.||Many farmers are already planning to scale back crop planting acreage due to decreased irrigation water allocations again in 2015.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a wet December for most of the area, January returned to an extremely dry pattern with the California drought continuing in full force. This was the driest January on record for the state, with many locations receiving little or no precipitation for what is on average the wettest month of the year. Snow pack in the mountains was extremely low, about 25% of normal. |Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.  |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. |Impacts to the region for January included strong conservation efforts within most communities, a significant decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Northern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, and a reduction of ground water resources which are replacing diminished reservoir water.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of January, 2015. Precipitation fell on only a few days of the month, and mostly across Kern County. Snowfall in the Sierra Nevada was limited to the highest elevations due to the warm nature of the storms that did move through. Temperatures remained well above normal throughout central California.  ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures continued into 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Impacts to the region for February included strong conservation efforts within most communities, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Northern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, and a reduction of ground water resources which are replacing diminished reservoir water. Farmers planned to reduce planting acreage due to projected reduction in irrigation water allocations.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After an extremely dry January for most areas, February had below normal precipitation, with a few exceptions. Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80. Some temporary improvement to Severe drought was seen over the Coastal Range due to a wet system early in the month.|Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of February, 2015. Precipitation continued to be below normal for the month with well above normal temperatures. Snowfall in the Sierra Nevada was limited to the highest elevations until the end of the month when a storm on February 28 brought snow levels down to about 5000 feet.  ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued into 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of February, 2015. Precipitation continued to be below normal for the month with well above normal temperatures. Snowfall in the Sierra Nevada was limited to the highest elevations until the end of the month when a storm on February 28 brought snow levels down to about 5000 feet.  ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). EVENT_NARRATIVE: Impacts to the region for March included conservation efforts within most foothill communities. Increased water conservation measures were passed by the state to increase reductions further by limiting water use for lawn watering and added incentives to limit water use in hotels and restaurants  There was a continued reduction of ground water resources which are being used to replace diminished reservoir water. Agricultural impacts included orchard reduction, limits on planting and increased costs due to reliance on groundwater. Sutter County alone has lost an estimated 1100 agriculture related jobs. The Lake Don Pedro Community (La Grange and Coulterville)  adopted mandatory water conservation measures and water use restrictions effective March 9th due to the drought emergency and severe lack of water supply in Lake McClure, which is expected to go dry this summer.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely dry March followed a below normal February for most areas. This continued the 4th consecutive year of drought for the region. Mountain snowfall was very limited for the month. This along with record warmth over the area resulted in the lowest snow pack levels on record for the time of year. By the end of March, the snow pack was only about 5 percent of normal levels. Melting snow pack supplies about a third of the annual water supply for California. Reservoirs across the area by the end of March were already well below normal levels.||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.| |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.  ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas,  San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter,  Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Voluntary water conservation efforts reduced water usage by 3.6 percent statewide compared to March 2014. Governor Brown ordered mandatory restrictions of 25 percent statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted.||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells.||There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the mountains due to the lack of snow, with many resorts closing early.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of March, 2015. The month was exceptionally warm and much drier than normal. In fact, it was the warmest March ever in Fresno and the 3rd warmest on record in Bakersfield. March, 2015 was the 6th driest March on record in Fresno, tied with March, 1923 with a measly precipitation total of only six hundredths of an inch. The months unseasonably warm weather tied or established new records for high minimum and maximum temperatures on several occasions in the San Joaquin Valley. In fact, temperatures averaged above normal every single day of the month except the 1st, 2nd and 3rd.||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued through the first few months of 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought is impacting Lake County, with farmers clipping some wine grape vines, reducing irrigation needed this summer, while reducing their harvest. Agricultural jobs and related businesses have lost jobs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely dry March followed a below normal February for most areas. This continued the 4th consecutive year of drought for the region. Mountain snowfall was very limited for the month. This along with record warmth over the area resulted in the lowest snow pack levels on record for the time of year. By the end of March, the snow pack was only about 5 percent of normal levels. Melting snow pack supplies about a third of the annual water supply for California. Reservoirs across the area by the end of March were already well below normal levels.||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.| |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.  ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas,  San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter,  Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Voluntary water conservation efforts reduced water usage by 3.6 percent statewide compared to March 2014. EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Northern Sierra Nevada due to a well below normal snow pack. Many ski resorts ended their seasons early and shut down in March.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely dry March followed a below normal February for most areas. This continued the 4th consecutive year of drought for the region. Mountain snowfall was very limited for the month. This along with record warmth over the area resulted in the lowest snow pack levels on record for the time of year. By the end of March, the snow pack was only about 5 percent of normal levels. Melting snow pack supplies about a third of the annual water supply for California. Reservoirs across the area by the end of March were already well below normal levels.||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.| |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.  ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas,  San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter,  Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Voluntary water conservation efforts reduced water usage by 3.6 percent statewide compared to March 2014. Governor Brown ordered mandatory restrictions of 25 percent statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted.||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells.||There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the mountains due to the lack of snow, with many resorts closing early.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought is impacting the southern Sacramento Valley, with farmers reducing acres planted and removing some trees from orchards. An example of this is rice acreage, which has been cut back by about 25 percent. Agricultural jobs and related businesses have lost jobs. Air quality has suffered, with particulate levels at the highest levels in a decade for some locations.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought is impacting Lake County, with farmers clipping some wine grape vines, reducing irrigation needed this summer, while reducing their harvest. Agriculture and related businesses have lost jobs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continues as April was yet another below normal month for precipitation for much of the area. There was some mountain snowfall, but this did little to improve the snow pack, which remained at the lowest levels on record. By the end of April, the snow pack was only about 4 percent of normal levels. As a result, reservoirs across the area by the end of April remained well below normal levels with little or no spring rise, due to the lack of snow melt.||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.| |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.  ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas,  San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter,  Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted.||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells.||There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the mountains due to the lack of snow, with many resorts closing early in the month or having already closed in March.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of April, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. While there was some precipitation in April, it was not uniformly distributed. Fresno received 1.25 inches of rain (131% of normal) while Bakersfield received only 0.08 inches (15% of normal). Overall, seasonal rainfall amounts continued to be only 50-75 percent of normal across central California.   ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued through the first few months of 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continues to impact the southern Sacramento Valley, with farmers reducing acres planted and removing some trees from orchards. An example of this is rice acreage, which has been cut back by about 25 percent. Agriculture and related businesses have lost jobs. Air quality has suffered, with particulate levels at the highest levels in a decade for some locations.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continues as April was yet another below normal month for precipitation for much of the area. There was some mountain snowfall, but this did little to improve the snow pack, which remained at the lowest levels on record. By the end of April, the snow pack was only about 4 percent of normal levels. As a result, reservoirs across the area by the end of April remained well below normal levels with little or no spring rise, due to the lack of snow melt.||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80.| |Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect.  ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas,  San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter,  Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted.||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells.||There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the mountains due to the lack of snow, with many resorts closing early in the month or having already closed in March.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Northern Sierra Nevada due to a well below normal snow pack. Many ski resorts ended their seasons early in April, or had already shut down in March.

The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought.||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted.||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells.||There was a large decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the mountains due to the lack of snow, with many resorts closing early in the month or having already closed in March.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Agriculture continued to be impacted with reduced planting and harvest of spring crops, bringing a significant loss of jobs. Tree mortality across the Valley increased, including  even normally drought resistant oak trees. Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, dry, brown appearance of the turf. Some golf courses shut down for lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continues as May was yet another below normal month for precipitation for much of the area. There was some mountain precipitation in the form of rain, but much of it was focused along and east of the crest. Snow pack was at the lowest levels on record and by the end of the month was virtually nonexistent. As a result, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were at well below normal levels and were already beginning to drop. ||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80. ||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||As a result of continuing drought conditions, emergency legislation appropriated over $1 billion of additional funds for drought-related projects and activities.|The Administrations May Revision proposal includes an additional $2.2 billion for programs that protect and expand local water supplies, improve water conservation, and provide immediate relief to impacted communities. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Construction was begun of a $40 million temporary drought barrier on the West False River in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta was started to keep tidal salt water from contaminating drinking water to Bay Area residents.||Additional impacts included low spring runoff on fisheries and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

The California drought continued in full force during the month of May, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. While there was some precipitation in May, it was not uniformly distributed. Fresno received 0.57 inches of rain (133% of normal) while Bakersfield received 0.68 inches (377% of normal). Overall, seasonal rainfall amounts continued to be only 35-65 percent of normal across central California. ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued through the first few months of 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains.

Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Construction was begun of a $40 million temporary drought barrier on the West False River in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta was started to keep tidal salt water from contaminating drinking water to Bay Area residents.||Additional impacts included low spring runoff on fisheries and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow pack levels in the southern Cascades for May were only a small fraction of normal. Lake Shasta and other area reservoirs were well below normal levels as a result, reducing water supply and reducing hydro-electrical power generating potential.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continues as May was yet another below normal month for precipitation for much of the area. There was some mountain precipitation in the form of rain, but much of it was focused along and east of the crest. Snow pack was at the lowest levels on record and by the end of the month was virtually nonexistent. As a result, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were at well below normal levels and were already beginning to drop. ||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80. ||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||As a result of continuing drought conditions, emergency legislation appropriated over $1 billion of additional funds for drought-related projects and activities.|The Administrations May Revision proposal includes an additional $2.2 billion for programs that protect and expand local water supplies, improve water conservation, and provide immediate relief to impacted communities. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown were in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. Spring planting is being scaled back significantly, with many existing tree crops and vines being removed due to a lack of irrigation water. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Construction was begun of a $40 million temporary drought barrier on the West False River in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta was started to keep tidal salt water from contaminating drinking water to Bay Area residents.||Additional impacts included low spring runoff on fisheries and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Construction of a $40 million temporary drought barrier on the West False River in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta was completed. This barrier is used to keep tidal salt water from contaminating drinking water to Bay Area residents. The State Water Resources Control Board has a program that allowed riparian water right holders in the Delta to voluntarily cut back water use by 25% in exchange for assurances they would not face deeper curtailments during the June-September growing season.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through June with yet another below normal month for precipitation for much of the area. There was some mountain rain, but much of it was focused along and east of the crest. Without a snow pack, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were at well below normal levels and were continuing to drop. ||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80. ||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||As a result of continuing drought conditions, emergency legislation appropriated over $1 billion of additional funds for drought-related projects and activities. |The Administrations May Revision proposal includes an additional $2.2 billion for programs that protect and expand local water supplies, improve water conservation, and provide immediate relief to impacted communities. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

The California drought continues in full force during the month of June, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. While there was some precipitation in June, it was not uniformly distributed. Fresno received 0.01 of an inch of rain, while Bakersfield received 0.08 inches. Seasonal rainfall amounts for the lower elevations were 0 to 50 percent of normal, while the higher elevations were generally around normal for the month. ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued through the first few months of 2015. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. Also, communities in Central California interior face state mandated reductions in municipal water use.

Without a snow pack, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were at well below normal levels and were continuing to drop. ||Extreme drought was detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra south of Interstate 80. ||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||As a result of continuing drought conditions, emergency legislation appropriated over $1 billion of additional funds for drought-related projects and activities. |The Administrations May Revision proposal includes an additional $2.2 billion for programs that protect and expand local water supplies, improve water conservation, and provide immediate relief to impacted communities. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow pack in the Cascasdes was essentially non-existent by June. Lake Shasta and other area reservoirs were well below normal levels as a result, reducing water supply and reducing hydro-electrical power generating potential.

The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow pack in the Northern Sierra was essentially non-existent by June. Mountain reservoirs were below normal levels as a result, reducing water supply for to larger reservoirs and reducing hydro-electrical power generating potential.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Agriculture continued to be impacted with reduced planting and harvest of spring crops, bringing a significant loss of jobs. Tree mortality across the Valley increased, including  even normally drought resistant oak trees. Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, dry, brown appearance of the turf. Some golf courses shut down for lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns.

CZ_NAME_STR: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continues to impact Lake County, with farmers clipping some wine grape vines, reducing irrigation needed this summer, while also reducing their harvest. Agriculture and related businesses have continued to lose jobs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through July. While quite a few mountain locations received greater than normal precipitation due to moisture from the monsoon and from ex-hurricane Dolores, this made little impact on the drought overall. The main affects were in decreasing fire activity in areas where locally heavy rain fell. Without a snow pack, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were continuing to drop well below normal levels.||Extreme drought continued to be detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra. ||The warm, dry winter left vegetation parched and ready to burn. Wildfire activity was well above normal levels, with California experiencing 4,201 wildfires that consumed 100,000 acres through August 1, much higher than the five-year average of 2,729 fires burning 48,153 acres, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. The Rocky Fire alone burned 69,000 acres in Lake, Yolo and Colusa counties and destroyed 43 homes and 53 outbuildings as of August 6. Additional fast burning wildfires include the Wragg, Lowell, and Kyburz fires.||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

The California drought continues in full force during the month of July, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. July was a good month for precipitation as there were multiple monsoonal and tropical influxes of moisture into the area. However, this wasn't nearly enough to impact the drought situation. Rainfall totals for Fresno received 0.43 of an inch of rain, while Bakersfield received 0.04 inches. ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The general trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued this year. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. Also, communities in Central California interior face state mandated reductions in municipal water use.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continues to impact agriculture in the Delta. Wildlife such as the endangered Delta smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon are suffering losses due to changes from the drought, such as an increase in water temperature and salinity levels.

Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Agriculture continued to be impacted in July bringing a significant loss of jobs. Tree mortality across the Valley increased, including even normally drought resistant oak trees. Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, bringing a dry, brown appearance to the turf. Some golf courses shut down for lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through July. While quite a few mountain locations received greater than normal precipitation due to moisture from the monsoon and from ex-hurricane Dolores, this made little impact on the drought overall. The main affects were in decreasing fire activity in areas where locally heavy rain fell. Without a snow pack, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were continuing to drop well below normal levels.||Extreme drought continued to be detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra. ||The warm, dry winter left vegetation parched and ready to burn. Wildfire activity was well above normal levels, with California experiencing 4,201 wildfires that consumed 100,000 acres through August 1, much higher than the five-year average of 2,729 fires burning 48,153 acres, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. The Rocky Fire alone burned 69,000 acres in Lake, Yolo and Colusa counties and destroyed 43 homes and 53 outbuildings as of August 6. Additional fast burning wildfires include the Wragg, Lowell, and Kyburz fires.||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted. California Disaster Assistance Act money continued to be provided for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. ||Additional impacts included low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological affects on forests and wildlife.

The California drought continues in full force during the month of July, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. July was a good month for precipitation as there were multiple monsoonal and tropical influxes of moisture into the area. However, this wasn't nearly enough to impact the drought situation. Rainfall totals for Fresno received 0.43 of an inch of rain, while Bakersfield received 0.04 inches. ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The 2013-2014 water year (July 1 - June 30) concluded with Fresno setting its second driest on record (4.81 inches) and Bakersfield setting its third driest (2.41 inches). For the calendar year, 2014 was the warmest year on record for Fresno and Bakersfield. The general trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued this year. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. Also, communities in Central California interior face state mandated reductions in municipal water use.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continues to impact agriculture in the Delta. Wildlife such as the endangered Delta smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon are suffering losses due to changes from the drought, such as an increase in water temperature and salinity levels. Wildfires were enhanced, such as the Jerusalem Fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through August with little change. Without a snow pack for late spring/early summer, reservoirs across the area by the end of the month were continuing to drop well below normal levels. All major reservoirs across the state were less that 40% of capacity by the end of the month. Folsom Lake was down to 20% of capacity, approaching near-record low levels for August, seen last in 1977. ||Extreme drought continued to be detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra. ||The continued dry weather and periods of hot temperatures left vegetation parched and ready to burn. Wildfire activity was well above normal levels. ||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continue to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. Actual usage across California dropped an average of 27 percent. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences released a new report indicating that Californias ongoing drought will impact the states agricultural economy this year by an estimated $2.7 billion and eliminate more than 21,000 jobs. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted, along with California Disaster Assistance Act money for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. Approximately 743,642 boxes of food were distributed to 391,003 households in affected communities that suffered high levels of unemployment from the drought||Low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological continues to cause adverse affects on forests and wildlife, including the endangered Delta Smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon.

Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, bringing a dry, brown appearance to the turf, some remained shut down due to a lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns. Grass fires enhanced by the dry conditions were common.

The UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences released a new report indicating that Californias ongoing drought will impact the states agricultural economy this year by an estimated $2.7 billion and eliminate more than 21,000 jobs. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted, along with California Disaster Assistance Act money for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. Approximately 743,642 boxes of food were distributed to 391,003 households in affected communities that suffered high levels of unemployment from the drought||Low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological continues to cause adverse affects on forests and wildlife, including the endangered Delta Smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon.

The California drought continues in full force during the month of August, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. Neither, Fresno or Bakersfield received any precipitation during the month of August.||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The general trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued this year. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. Also, communities in Central California interior face state mandated reductions in municipal water use.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continued to impact Lake County, with a reduced harvest yield reported. The harvest was very early, mainly completed by the end of September. Grape sizes were smaller than normal. Extremely dry conditions increased wildfire danger.  The worst of these was the Valley Fire, which devastated multiple communities (see damage under wildfire entry).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through September with little change. Reservoirs across the area were continuing to drop well below normal levels. All major reservoirs across the state were less that 40% of capacity. Folsom Lake was down to 18% of capacity, approaching near-record low levels for September, seen last in 1977.  70 homes in Butte County are without well water. The numbers reflect cumulative reports of household water shortages by county reported to the state since January 2014.||A growing number of residential wells are running dry. The Household Water Supply Shortage Reporting System showed 70 homes in Butte County without well water. Other counties reported residential water shortages as follows: Tuolumne 333, Glenn County 27; Shasta County 2; Tehama County 34.||Extreme drought continued to be detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra. ||The continued dry weather and periods of hot temperatures left vegetation parched and ready to burn. Wildfire activity was far above normal levels in September, with the Valley Fire becoming the 3rd most destructive wildfire in California history, and the Butte Fire the 7th most destructive.||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continued to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences released a new report indicating that Californias ongoing drought will impact the states agricultural economy this year by an estimated $2.7 billion and eliminate more than 21,000 jobs. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted, along with California Disaster Assistance Act money for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. Approximately 743,642 boxes of food were distributed to 391,003 households in affected communities that suffered high levels of unemployment from the drought. Nonprofit organizations in the San Joaquin Valley were struggling to meet the needs of their clients for drought-related programs. One area crop which is being heavily impacted is rice production, which is expected to fall by about 30 percent due to water shortages.||Low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological continues to cause adverse affects on forests and wildlife, including the endangered Delta Smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon. High temperatures in the Sacramento River are having a particularly strong effect on young salmon, and could repeat the major fish kill seen in the summer of 2014.||Air quality in the Valley has been poor throughout the drought, particularly in the San Joaquin Valley, due to the lack of rain to wash particles from the air and dust from unplanted fields and newly dug wells. Smoke from recent fires has worsened air quality significantly, causing problems even for healthy people. Asthma has become a much bigger problem in the Valley since the start of the drought.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought continues to impact agriculture in the Delta. Wildlife such as the endangered Delta smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon are suffering losses due to changes from the drought, such as an increase in water temperature and salinity levels. Wildfire activity was enhanced.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Agriculture continued to be impacted in September during the harvest, with a significant loss of jobs. Rice production was forecast to drop by 30 percent in the Sacramento Valley. Bee keepers scaled back honey production due to a lack of nectar and honey to sustain their bees. Tree mortality across the Valley increased, including even normally drought resistant oak trees. Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, bringing a dry, brown appearance to the turf, and some remained shut down due to a lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns. Grass fires enhanced by the dry conditions were common.

Rice production was forecast to drop by 30 percent in the Sacramento Valley. Tree mortality across the Valley increased, including even normally drought resistant oak trees. Golf courses faced pressure to use less water and were doing so, bringing a dry, brown appearance to the turf, and some remained shut down due to a lack of water. Many people reduced landscape watering at homes or removed grass lawns. Grass fires enhanced by the dry conditions were common. Wildlife such as the winter run Chinook Salmon in the Sacramento River suffered losses due to changes from the drought, such as an increase in water temperature.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long term drought continued through September with little change. Reservoirs across the area were continuing to drop well below normal levels. All major reservoirs across the state were less that 40% of capacity. Folsom Lake was down to 18% of capacity, approaching near-record low levels for September, seen last in 1977.  70 homes in Butte County are without well water. The numbers reflect cumulative reports of household water shortages by county reported to the state since January 2014.||A growing number of residential wells are running dry. The Household Water Supply Shortage Reporting System showed 70 homes in Butte County without well water. Other counties reported residential water shortages as follows: Tuolumne 333, Glenn County 27; Shasta County 2; Tehama County 34.||Extreme drought continued to be detected by the U.S. Drought Monitor across most the region, with exceptional drought for the northern San Joaquin Valley, the central and southern Sacramento Valley, the Burney Basin and the Sierra. ||The continued dry weather and periods of hot temperatures left vegetation parched and ready to burn. Wildfire activity was far above normal levels in September, with the Valley Fire becoming the 3rd most destructive wildfire in California history, and the Butte Fire the 7th most destructive.||Governor Jerry Brown declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California January 17, 2014 and this continued to be in effect. ||Local Emergency Proclamations have been issued for El Dorado, Glenn, Lake, Plumas, San Joaquin, Shasta, Sutter, Tuolumne, and Yuba counties. The cities of Live Oak Lodi, and Ripon continue in a drought emergency. Drought task forces have been established in Butte, Lake, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, San Joaquin, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tuolumne, and Yolo counties to coordinate response to the drought. ||Mandatory water reductions of 25 percent as ordered by Governor Brown continued to be in effect statewide, the first time such mandatory restrictions have been enacted. ||Agriculture has been heavily impacted, with numerous farm and farm related jobs lost. The UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences released a new report indicating that Californias ongoing drought will impact the states agricultural economy this year by an estimated $2.7 billion and eliminate more than 21,000 jobs. The state continued to supply food assistance to those impacted, along with California Disaster Assistance Act money for those who have lost drinking water due to dry wells. Approximately 743,642 boxes of food were distributed to 391,003 households in affected communities that suffered high levels of unemployment from the drought. Nonprofit organizations in the San Joaquin Valley were struggling to meet the needs of their clients for drought-related programs. One area crop which is being heavily impacted is rice production, which is expected to fall by about 30 percent due to water shortages.||Low runoff in streams and rivers on fish and ecological continues to cause adverse affects on forests and wildlife, including the endangered Delta Smelt and winter run Chinook Salmon. High temperatures in the Sacramento River are having a particularly strong effect on young salmon, and could repeat the major fish kill seen in the summer of 2014.||Air quality in the Valley has been poor throughout the drought, particularly in the San Joaquin Valley, due to the lack of rain to wash particles from the air and dust from unplanted fields and newly dug wells. Smoke from recent fires has worsened air quality significantly, causing problems even for healthy people. Asthma has become a much bigger problem in the Valley since the start of the drought.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California ski resorts were offering incentives, such as discounts or guarantees to increase sales of season passes, which have been hurt in recent years by poor snow conditions. Dry conditions resulted in a continued loss of trees, numbering potentially in the millions, with heightened wildfire activity (see Butte Fire entry).

The California drought continues in full force during the month of September, 2015. Temperatures continued to average above normal. Fresno received 0.12 inch of rainfall while Bakersfield only received a trace of precipitation during the month of September. ||The U.S. Drought Monitor continued to report exceptional drought conditions across the entire Central California region. This extent of exceptional drought is extremely unusual for California. The general trend of below normal precipitation and above normal temperatures has continued this year. ||There continues to be significant media coverage on the on-going drought conditions. These reports include discussion of significant re-allocation of water resources from the east to west side of the San Joaquin Valley, farmers forgoing planting of some crops, a decrease in the snow-related tourism activity in the Southern Sierra Nevada, reduction in air quality due to persistent stagnant air, loss or reduction of ground water, wells drying up in several communities leaving them with no water, and an unprecedented increase in fire danger across the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains. Also, communities in Central California interior face state mandated reductions in municipal water use.
